awd_titl_txt: Epitranscriptomic regulation of codon biased stress response genes in Escherichia coli
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will help characterize new ways in which cells control the flow of genetic information, particularly when responding to stress and to conserve energy. Chemical modifications of RNA, which are known to regulate gene expression, may be biased toward targeting certain genes over others due to specific sequences within the genetic code known as synonymous codons. The research will explore this phenomenon, which remains poorly understood thus far, especially in bacteria. The project will thus advance how gene expression regulation is at the frontier of genetics and biotechnological development. The project will also provide opportunities to train under-represented minority graduate and undergraduate students in cutting edge techniques in genetics and molecular biology. In addition, it will provide the scientific basis for outreach to faith-based communities through lectures at high school and divinity schools. 

The genetic mechanisms used to quickly respond to cellular stressors are not completely understood. While transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulators are thought to be primary effectors of cellular stress responses, recent studies suggest an emerging role for the epitranscriptome (RNA modifications) in the stress response toolbox. While it is clear that RNA modifications have an influence on stress response gene regulation, it is not clear how they target specific genes for regulation. The hypothesis addressed in this project is that synonymous leucine and serine codon bias provide a basis for epitranscriptomic targeting of stress response genes for regulatory purposes. This hypothesis will be tested by measuring expression of heat shock genes, with genetically engineered modified synonymous leucine or serine codon usage ratios, in the absence of specific tRNA modifications. Ribosome profiling in the absence of RNA modifications will also be performed to determine the sensitivity of specific codons to RNA modifications. The project will be a vehicle for training under-represented minority graduate and undergraduate students in cutting edge techniques in genetics and molecular biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SCIENTIFIC RESULTS AND SOCIETAL BROADER IMPACT

During the grant period, key research activities advanced our understanding of RNA modifications, heat shock proteins, and their regulatory mechanisms. A major research focus was the computational analysis of leucine and serine codon biases in 40 heat shock proteins of E. coli and their relationships with RNA modifications (i6A, cmo5U, and C/Um). Another key study identified small RNA regulators of miaA expression. A genetic screen for small RNA regulation of the miaAP2-HS transcript pointed to CsrB as a regulator, a finding confirmed through reporter gene assays and Northern blot analysis.

Further investigation explored the role of CsrB in miaA expression, particularly its effects on miaA mRNA stability and CsrA levels, which in turn influence MiaA protein stability. Additional experiments suggested that RNase E is involved in miaA RNA processing. Another study examined how RNA modifications affect Hfq expression, revealing that mutations in genes encoding RNA modification enzymes (truA, mnmG, tgt) led to reduced Hfq protein levels, demonstrating that RNA modifications are essential for normal translation.

The research also contributed to the development of genetic tools for controlling heat shock gene expression and initiated pilot ribosome profiling studies to examine how RNA modifications impact ribosome footprints.. The findings indicated that UUX-Leu and UCX-Ser codon biases are associated with increased ribosome pausing, providing new insights into how RNA modifications influence translation efficiency. Furthermore, that modifications are necessary for the full expression of major heat shock proteins GroL and GroS

Impact Summary:  These discoveries have broad implications for microbiology, stress response mechanisms, and gene regulation, with potential applications extending to other biological systems, including eukaryotic cells and human tissues. Beyond research, this project strengthened scientific infrastructure at Howard University and engaged in outreach efforts to faith-based communities, fostering discussions on the intersection of science and religion.

STEM TRAINING AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IMPACT

The Thompson Laboratory, with this NSF support, has been deeply committed to mentoring and training the next generation of scientists, physicians, educators, and professionals in national security. Over the past five years, the lab has trained five Ph.D. students and more than 20 undergraduates, many of whom have been accepted into top graduate and professional programs. Notably, two Ph.D. dissertations were directly supported by this funding.

Undergraduate trainees have achieved significant recognition, with 20% receiving prestigious STEM awards, including three Goldwater Scholarships, the Inaugural Rising Black Scientist Award from Cell Press, and an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship honorable mention. One current trainee is a Fulbright Fellowship finalist. Thompson Lab graduates have been accepted into leading Ph.D. and M.D./Ph.D. programs at institutions such as Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Pittsburgh, University of Michigan, Tufts University, University of North Carolina and New York University. Others have gained admission to highly competitive medical schools, including Harvard Medical School, Johns Hopkins University, Howard University, University of Florida, and the Kaiser Permanente School of Medicine. Additionally, graduates have secured post-baccalaureate research positions at the National Institutes of Health, Vanderbilt University, and the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Many students have participated in competitive summer internships at MIT, UC Berkeley, Johns Hopkins University, Washington University in St. Louis, University of Wisconsin at Madison, and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (Janelia Farm).

Beyond academia, Thompson Lab alumni generated through this NSF grant period have pursued impactful careers in national security, education, and research. One of the Ph.D. graduates supported by this grant is now a national security analyst applying scientific expertise to defense and intelligence. Another has become a K-12 STEM educator dedicated to developing the next generation of scientists and engineers. We accepted students from broad STEM and non-STEM majors, including biology, chemical engineering, psychology, political science, and computer science. The lab’s interdisciplinary training ensures that students are well-equipped for careers that advance science, support national security, and promote STEM education.

Overall Scientific and Training Imacts. These research and training achievements were made possible through NSF funding, facilitating advances in RNA modification research. The integration of genetic, biochemical, and computational approaches underscores the power of interdisciplinary research and innovation.

By cultivating highly skilled scientists, educators, and professionals, this NSF funded  project has contributed to expanding the nation’s STEM expertise, strengthening national security, and maintaining leadership in cutting-edge research. The opportunities provided through this funding have prepared the next generation of scientific leaders with the knowledge, skills, and networks necessary for future success. As these individuals advance in their careers, they will drive scientific discovery, enhance the United States’ global standing in science and technology, and inspire future generations. In this way, the NSF grant has not only propelled the success of the Thompson Lab but has also laid the foundation for transformative contributions to STEM fields that will benefit the nation in the years to come.
